title: What will Elon Musk's Neuralink chip do to my brain? Will it make me a genius or something? - Quora

response.answer_text: > What will Elon Musk's Neuralink chip do to my brain? Will it make me a genius or something? It won’t do a thing. Elon Musk is talking out of his ass, and people are falling for it. This is wishful thinking and “think of the possibilities!!!” kind of thing. The dude wants reality to be a Cyberpunk world. We aren’ there yet. In other words it is something like “Imagine the future where everybody is interconnected, where at speed of thought you can access any informational resource, control your home and communicate with people wirelessly, like a telepath! What if such future becomes possible?” Sounds nice, right? However, this is total fiction, and a “what if” scenario. Eventually they might arrive at prototype which will react to commands spoken in your mind with 90% chance. As this was done before in 2011. Then they’ll need to deal with medical approval, most likely. Then you’ll arrive at unimpressive product that allows you to unlock your phone by thinking “Ok, Google” instead of speaking it… at a mere cost of 300000$ you have to pay for the surgery which has a 10% chance of making you a vegetable, and it would have no further capabilities beyond that. Elon Musk describes his dream vision. The dream vision is cool, however, it does not correspond to an actual product. They don’t have a product, as they didn’t demonstrate anything. There’s nothing. Only dream vision. The ability enhancing shadowrun chips that boosts your intelligence are long time away. They require deep brain understanding, which is likely to be achieved by Blue Brain folks and not Elon.  Regarding presentation itself:  Fun parts: “To cause no trauma (corrects himself) to cause minimal trauma”“it is wireless like bluetooth”They spent their entire time talking about wire inserting robots.And they did not demonstrate any product. The beginning and the end of the presentation is “think of the possibilities!” Possibilities they have not implemented. At this point it is just a promise. That is not likely to come true. I also wonder how those tiny wires are going to survive any possible mechanical interference (i.e. whether brushing your hair would tear them due to movement of skin, interact with magnetic fields, or electric/static discharge. Wireless nature of the device is source of concern, especially the part where they talk about connecting to the phone, and not needing any programmer. It means this thing is hackable, and like I said, it is gonna be an operation that lets you turn on your phone. Kinda an overkill. The guy at the end pretty much says that while they can insert the needless, they have not yet decoded the movement, imply that the device requires fine tuning, plus is unable to distinguish between real, observed and thought movement. This is just great. Or rather “great”. So if we summarize it, they came up with a way to insert electrodes into human brain, but they have not decoded the signals, they have no products and the idea is to make the device wireless and easy to access. The joke about “update it via blutooth” is especially annoying, as this is the brain we’re talking about. Very funny. I also wondered if Musk is well, as he stutters quite a lot. So, it is very unimpressive. To be more precise, the robot itself likely will have future use, but they don’t have the brain computer interface they’re promising. Or, they don’t have a protocol for interacting with it, and they’re promising to figure it out next year with human trials…. Sigh. And with just that being displayed peole have their imagination running wild. I saw a deluge of questions fitting for cyberpunk age since the announcement….

The current version is only intended to help if you’re a quadriplegic or have some serious medical condition it can treat. As it evolves through different improved future versions, yeah it might make you a genius giving you immediate access to cloud based AI as though it was just part of your brain. Suppose you could google anything just by thinking about it. Do any calculation. Translate other languages. Store anything you want to remember in the cloud for instant access. You’d certainly seem a lot smarter than you do now.

The Neuralink chip won’t do anything to your brain. Neuralink, as it is currently being developed, is a sensor composed of super-fine wires attached next to neural pathways. It senses the state of the neuron, deriving information from the rate and pattern of the cell’s firing. It doesn’t have any active effect on the brain. The end result is for the human brain to be able directly interface (one way) with a computer system.
